results.title: Broadcast news (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Gracie Films, James L. Brooks Films and James L. Brooks
results.brief_description: Three ambitious workaholics are set loose in a network TV newsroom where their professional and personal lives become hopelessly cross wired. Writer-director James L. Brooks is a filmmaker who is able to brilliantly combine comedy and drama with rich characters and unforgettable dialogue. His satire on the media can also be seen on ‘The Simpsons’ for which he is Executive Producer. He paints a savage, knowing, hilarious look at the television news industry and also what can happen to your personal life when your job consumes you. The performances are simply phenomenal. William Hurt gives depth to a dimbulb anchor, but Holly Hunter and Albert Brooks walk away with the movie. Cast includes Jack Nicholson (unbilled) and Joan Cusack. Music by Bill Conti.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Gracie Films, James L. Brooks Films and James L. Brooks

results.title: Broad waterways
results.creator_credit: British Transport Films, Stewart McAllister and Kenneth J. Fairbairn
results.brief_description: A film about Britain’s channel system, concentrating on the North Eastern Division, based in Leeds. It shows the redevelopment of the channels, locks, and docks to increase the efficiency of water transportation.

results.title: Broad shots
results.brief_description: Broad Shots was made by a group of young women from Broadmeadows as part of the Broadmeadows Healthy Localities Project, a local youth health promotion project. It looks at the issue of violence against young women through a series of interviews, skits and voxpops. “Broad Shots” is funny and fast and is a good starting point for discussion on domestic violence, sexual harassment and assertiveness. It is targeted at young people aged 13 to 16 years. Also contains appearances by comediennes Judith Lucy and Magda Szubanski.

results.title: Broad jump
results.creator_credit: United States Olympic Association, Amateur Athletic Union and Edmund Dorfmann
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “United World Track and Field”
Shows the development of the technique of broad jump, aka long jump, through to its correct conception and exercise. The balanced development of mobility and well performed athlete.

results.title: Broad daylight
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and Derrick Knight
results.brief_description: The development and use of patent glazing from Victorian times to the present day. Shows how patent glazing derived from the needs of expanding Victorian industry, and how it developed techniques so that today it remains completely adaptable to the demands of contemporary design.

results.title: British Transport Films. 1. The Classics
results.creator_credit: British Transport Films and Edgar H. Anstey
results.brief_description: British Transport Films (BTF) began in May 1949 boasting one of Britain’s leading documentary filmmakers, Edgar Anstey, as its head. Between 1950 and 1980 a huge range of quality films were produced with many gaining top awards at various film festivals. This is a compilation of a selection of four films, digitally remastered by the British Film Institute, demonstrating the diversity and high calibre of BTF as a production company. Elizabethan express: From King’s Cross Station, London, to Waverley Station, Edinburgh, is 393 miles. The Elizabethan - a summertime express - does this journey in six and a half hours non-stop - the longest daily non-stop run in the world to be timed at over 60 mph in 1954. This film is about one of those runs and the people behind the service. (See also Title Code 003232 16mm) Snowdrift at Bleath Gill: A freight train becomes snowbound in the West-Morland hills in Northern England. The Motive Power, Operating and Engineering Departments of British Transport go to work with snow-ploughs to reach the trapped train. Working through the night the team dig clear, and thaw out moving parts, and finally two engines help to clear the line. (See also Title Code 009948 16mm) Train time: An account of the operation of British Railways. The integration of goods and passenger services calls for a constant review of time-tables to meet the varying local needs. (See also Title Code 011098 16mm) Forward to first principles: Tells the history of freight railways and the laying of iron lines, of the impact on the geography and landscape of Great Britain and of the age of computer technology and remote control replacing manual labour.

results.title: British scrapbook. Parts 1 and 2
results.creator_credit: Directorate of Army Kinematography (The War Office)
results.brief_description: A scrapbook look at World War II using some captured enemy film, but mostly film shot by the military cameramen of the forces of the United Nations. Part one: June 1940-October 1942; Part two: November 1942-December 1944.
results.description: A scrapbook look at World War II using some captured enemy film, but mostly film shot by the military cameramen of the forces of the United Nations. Part one: June 1940-October 1942; Part two: November 1942-December 1944.

results.title: British Mutoscope featuring Charlie Chaplin reel
results.brief_description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope.

constellations_primary.name: Perception, time and flickering images
constellations_primary.description: Using a peep hole and a loop of rotating still images, mutoscopes control the point of view of the audience while also creating the illusion of depth. Filmmakers have since put optical tricks to work creating surreal scenes.

results.description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.
description_for_label: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.
